Description: Hollow-cast, copper alloy votive box, also known as relic-box or animal coffin; rectangular case surmounted by a solid-cast figure of a short elongated snake (or eel?), which head is broken off; one eyelet for suspension on one corner of top of base; surface corroded and blackened (burnt); case complete with small back still sealed; such case should contain a mummified snake (or parts of).
Findspot: Found/Acquired: Town (Naukratis), House of 'cache of bronzes' (probably)
Curator's comments: More than a hundred of votive boxes were discovered in Naukratis. The bulk of them originate from a building located in the southern part of the city (Petrie 1886, 41-42). This specimen could originate from this cache that can be dated around the end of the 5th-beginning of the 4th century BC (Masson 2015). However, Griffith signalled in his notes from January 1885 several bronze reptile cases in a trench located outside the Great Temenos (Masson forthcoming b). Most of Naukratis votive boxes displayed a figure of a reptile (lizard and snake) or an eel, such as this one. Reptiles are particularly associated with the solar god and demiurge Atum (for the snake relic-box: Weiss 2012, 276-278). Snake votive boxes pertain particularly to the types T 13 and T 14 in the typology of animal bronzes by K. Weiss (Weiss 2012, 725-731, Taf. 42c-e, 75a/g, 77l, Typ T 13 and T 14, esp. Nr. 741-743, 745-746, 750-754, 758-762, 764-767 from Naukratis). For this specimen, Weiss proposes the type T 14 (Weiss 2012, Nr. 766). Type T 14 usually represents a coiled snake, looped over itself to form a figure of eight (Taf. 42d-e), though in some instances, a short elongated snake is possible (Taf. 42f). Type T 13 represents a snake with head erect (raised cobra/uraeus). Since the head of the snake on this relic-box is damaged, it is uncertain to which type this votive box pertains. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London, 41-42. Masson, A. 2015, ‘Cult and Trade. A reflexion on Egyptian metal offerings from Naukratis’, in D. Robinson and F. Goddio (eds), Thonis Heracleion in Context, Oxford Centre for Maritime Archaeology Monograph 8, Oxford, 71-88. Masson, A. forthcoming b, ‘Naukratis: Egyptian offerings in context’, in M. Bergeron and A. Masson (eds), Naukratis in Context: Cults, Sanctuaries and Offerings, Proceedings of the second Naukratis workshop, held at the British Museum 22nd – 23rd June 2013. Weiss, K. 2012, Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten : Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland, Ägypten und Altes Testament 81.
Bibliographic references: Weiss 2012 / Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten : Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland (Typ T 14, Nr. 766) (right type?)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (MB.058) (phase 2)
